column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Why did NASA decide to take the route of distributed computing ?
#Text=Will they do this again ?
#Text=I would n't say that NASA decided to do this — the idea for Stardust@home originated here at U. C. Berkeley .
#Text=Part of the idea of course came …
#Text=If I understand correctly it is n't distributed computing , but distributed eyeballing ?
#Text=…from the SETI@home people who are just down the hall from us .

#Text=But as Brian just pointed out . this is not really distributed computing like SETI@home the computers are just platforms for the VM and it is human eyes and brains who are doing the real work which makes it fun ( IMHO ) .
#Text=That said …
#Text=There have been quite a few people who have expressed interested in developing automated algorithms for searching .
#Text=Just because WE do n't know how to write such an algorithm does n't mean nobody does .
#Text=We 're delighted at this and are happy to help make it happen
#Text=Is n't there a catch 22 that the data you 're going to collect would be a prerequisite to automating the process ?
#Text=That was the conclusion that we came to early on — that we would need some sort of training set to be able to train an algorithm .
#Text=Of course you have to train people too , but we 're hoping ( we 'll see ! ) that people are more flexible in recognizing things that they 've never seen before and pointing them out .
#Text=Our experience is that people who have never seen a track in aerogel can learn to recognize them very quickly , even against a big background of cracks , dust and other sources of confusion ...
#Text=Coming back to the original question — although NASA did n't originate the idea , they are very generously supporting this project .
#Text=It would n't have happened without NASA 's financial support ( and of course access to the Stardust collector ) .
#Text=Did that answer the question ?
#Text=Will a project like this be done again ?
#Text=I do n't know ...
#Text=There are only a few projects for which this approach makes sense ...
#Text=In fact , I frankly have n't run across another at least in Space Science .
#Text=But I am totally open to the idea of it .
#Text=I am not in favor of just doing it as " make-work " — that is just artificially taking this approach when another approach would make more sense .
#Text=How did the idea come up to do this kind of project ?
#Text=Really desperation .
#Text=When we first thought about this we assumed that we would use some sort of automated image recognition technique .

#Text=We asked some experts around here in CS and the conclusion was that the problem was somewhere between trivial and impossible , and we would n't know until we had some real examples to work with .
#Text=So we talked with Dan Wertheimer and Dave Anderson ( literally down the hall from us ) about the idea of a distributed project , and they were quite encouraging .
#Text=Dave proposed the VM machinery , and Josh Von Korff , a physics grad student , implemented it .
#Text=( Beautifully , I think .
#Text=I take no credit ! )
